data.title: Shoott to Partner with TechCon SoCal 2026
data.description:
New York, New York--(Newsfile Corp. - February 28, 2026) - Shoott is pleased to announce that the company will be participating in TechCon SoCal 2026. This year’s event will be held May 22, 23 at the San Diego State University in San Diego, California.

As a partner, Shoott will be collaborating with TechCon Global to support, promote, and drive engagement at the event.

TechCon SoCal, produced by TechCon Global, is a leading technology and innovation event that brings together investors, founders, thought leaders, and industry experts. The 2026 program features keynotes, panel discussions, fireside discussions, and demos on emerging technologies shaping the future of business.

Attendees interested in learning more about TechCon SoCal 2026 or registering for the conference can visit here.

About Shoott

Shoott is an AAPI female-run startup that seeks to make professional photography more accessible to everyone. Shoott offers 5-star rated "Insta-worthy" photo sessions that are free to book, where clients pay only for photos they love. A trusted partner with Meta, Google, Forbes, Microsoft, Salesforce, American Express, Avalara, Upwork, Bytedance, L'Oreal, and more.

About TechCon Global:

TechCon Global is a leading organization founded in 2019, dedicated to connecting entrepreneurs, investors, and industry leaders through high-impact innovation events. We empower innovation and foster investment ecosystems that drive sustainable growth and meaningful change worldwide. Our programs blend operator insight with a practical innovation approach, supported by mentors, acurated innovation platform, and access to business investors for startups. Driven by purpose and passion, we continue to expand our reach, uniting bold thinkers, visionary founders, and impact-driven investors, guided by a consistent innovation approach that turns ideas into outcomes.

For further information, please contact:

Shoott

Jennifer Tsay

646-335-5023

jennifer@shoott.com

https://shoott.com

data.title: OpenAI: Pentagon deal has stronger guardrails than Anthropic's
data.description:
OpenAI said on Saturday that its agreement with the Pentagon "has more guardrails than any previous agreement for classified AI deployments, including Anthropic's."

Open AI firm said that the contract struck on Friday to deploy technology in the U.S. Defense Department's classified network enforces three red lines: no use of OpenAI technology on mass domestic surveillance, no directing autonomous weapons systems and no high-stakes automated decisions.

data.title: Daqo New Energy: Cyclical Inflection or Value Trap?
data.description:
Daqo New Energy posted its first positive EBITDA in six quarters during Q3 2025, reporting $45.8 million in adjusted earnings as polysilicon prices recovered from $4.19/kg to $5.80/kg. The company sold 42,406 metric tons against production of just 30,650 MT, drawing down inventory accumulated during the brutal downturn that saw prices collapse 85% from 2022's $39/kg peak. With zero debt and $2.21 billion in cash and investments, Daqo possesses the balance sheet to outlast weaker competitors. But the company's 40% capacity utilization rate and production costs of $6.38/kg that still exceed selling prices raise fundamental questions about whether this cyclical inflection represents genuine recovery or merely a temporary reprieve in a structurally oversupplied industry.

Business Model: Pure-Play Polysilicon Commodity Exposure

Daqo operates a 305,000 MT annual polysilicon production facility in Xinjiang, China, using the modified Siemens process to produce high-purity silicon for photovoltaic manufacturers. Unlike vertically integrated competitors, Daqo sells exclusively into the spot market with no downstream wafer or cell operations to hedge commodity price volatility. The company has shifted its product mix toward N-type polysilicon, which now represents 70% of production compared to 40% in 2023. N-type material enables higher-efficiency solar cells and commands premium pricing, with Q3 2025 transactions ranging from RMB 49-55/kg versus RMB 32-35/kg for P-type material.

The polysilicon production process is energy-intensive, requiring 52-55 kilowatt-hours per kilogram at Daqo's facilities. This positions the company well below China's new mandatory energy consumption standard of 64 kWh/kg-Si, which took effect in September 2025. Producers exceeding this threshold must implement corrective improvements or face production restrictions. Industry estimates suggest 20-30% of older capacity may struggle to meet this standard, though the actual enforcement timeline and impact remain unclear. For Daqo, the regulation reinforces its cost advantage rather than creating immediate capacity rationalization. For Daqo, this regulation transforms a cost advantage into a regulatory moat.

Q3 2025: First Positive Quarter After Six Quarters of Losses

The Q3 2025 results marked a decisive turning point. Revenue jumped to $244.6 million from $75.2 million in Q2, driven by a 134% increase in sales volume and a 38% recovery in average selling prices. Gross margin turned positive at 3.9% compared to Q2's negative 108%, reflecting higher prices, lower production costs, and the benefit of inventory impairment write-downs taken earlier in the cycle. EBITDA margin reached 18.7%, up from Q2's negative 64%.

The cost structure improved meaningfully. Cash costs declined to $4.54/kg from $5.12/kg in Q2, representing an 11% sequential improvement and the lowest in the company's history. Total production costs fell to $6.38/kg from $7.26/kg. Operating at 40% capacity utilization, Daqo produced 30,650 MT while selling 42,406 MT, depleting inventory by roughly 11,750 MT to reach what management termed "healthy levels." This inventory drawdown was strategicDaqo capitalized on favorable pricing to monetize stockpiles accumulated when prices traded below cash costs.

However, the company still reported a GAAP net loss of $14.9 million, driven by operational losses of $20.3 million and an operating margin of negative 8.3%. Adjusted net income of $3.7 million excluded $18.6 million in non-cash share-based compensation, underscoring that profitability remains fragile even at the elevated Q3 price levels.

Per-Kilogram Economics: The Unit-Level Profitability Challenge

Understanding Daqo's economics requires dissecting costs and revenues at the per-kilogram level. In Q3 2025:

  • Average Selling Price: $5.80/kg
  • Cash Cost: $4.54/kg
  • Total Production Cost: $6.38/kg (cash cost + $1.84/kg depreciation)
  • Gross Margin: 3.9% (boosted by inventory write-off reversals)
  • Normalized Gross Margin: Negative when excluding inventory accounting benefits

Cash costs of $4.54/kg represent a 78% cash recovery rate against the $5.80/kg ASP, leaving $1.26/kg in gross cash generation before depreciation. This $1.26/kg must cover $1.84/kg in depreciation plus all corporate overhead. With Q3 SG&A of $32 million spread across 42,406 MT sold, overhead adds another $0.75/kg, bringing total cost to roughly $7.13/kg against $5.80/kg revenuea $1.33/kg shortfall.

The company's full-year 2025 guidance of 121,000-124,000 MT production implies annualized capacity utilization of approximately 40%. At this utilization rate, Daqo's fixed cost burden remains elevated. Depreciation of $1.84/kg reflects assets designed for 305,000 MT annual output, meaning each kilogram of actual production must absorb 2.5x its proportionate share of fixed costs. Idle facility maintenance cost $0.16/kg in Q3, further eroding economics.

For Daqo to achieve sustainable profitability, one of three conditions must occur:

  • Polysilicon prices rise to $8.50-9.00/kg (47% above Q3 levels)
  • Cash costs decline below $4.00/kg (12% further reduction)
  • Utilization rates approach 75-80% to spread fixed costs

Owner Economics: What Does Owning This Business Actually Mean?

Viewing Daqo through an owner's lens reveals uncomfortable truths about commodity manufacturing businesses with high fixed costs and no pricing power. An outright owner of Daqo effectively purchases $6.7 billion in gross property, plant and equipment (depreciated to $2.8 billion net book value) operating at 40% capacity in a market where oversupply is forcing coordinated production cuts. The owner's return depends entirely on the polysilicon spot pricea variable beyond management's control.

Consider the cash generation profile. At Q3's 40% utilization and $5.80/kg pricing, Daqo generates $53 million in quarterly gross cash ($1.26/kg 42,406 MT), or roughly $212 million annualized. Corporate overhead of $128 million annually ($32M 4 quarters) reduces owner cash flow to $84 million before taxes, maintenance capex, and working capital swings. This represents a 3.8% cash-on-cash return on the $2.2 billion market capitalizationworse than U.S. Treasury bills.

The asset turnover is equally concerning. Daqo generated $244.6 million in Q3 revenue (~$978 million annualized) against $2.8 billion in net PP&E, implying 0.35x asset turnover. Best-in-class manufacturers target 1.0-1.5x turnover, but commodity businesses operating below 50% utilization structurally cannot achieve this. An owner is thus paying for dormant capacity that may never generate returns.

The cyclical asymmetry compounds the problem. During upcycles, polysilicon prices mean-revert from oversupplied lows toward marginal cost, allowing efficient producers like Daqo to earn attractive returns for 12-18 months. But during downcycles, prices can trade below cash costs for years, as occurred from Q1 2024 through Q3 2025. The owner must fund cumulative losses during prolonged troughs, which can exceed the profits earned during brief peaks.

Daqo's debt-free balance sheet and $2.21 billion in liquid assets provide crucial optionalitythe owner can survive extended downturns and potentially acquire distressed capacity. But this cash represents 98% of the current market capitalization, implying the market values the operating business at just $440 million ($2.64B market cap - $2.21B cash). Stated differently, investors are paying $1.44/kg of annual capacity ($440M 305,000 MT) for a business generating $1.26/kg in gross cash at 40% utilization.

The owner's worst-case scenario involves permanent demand destruction or technological substitution. If fluidized bed reactor processes mature to produce N-type material at meaningfully lower costs, Daqo's Siemens-based assets could become stranded. The owner would face a binary outcome: operate at cash-burning levels to maintain optionality, or permanently idle facilities and crystallize losses.

Through-Cycle Economics: What Does Daqo Actually Earn?

Looking at Q3 2025 in isolation misses the point. The real question for long-term owners is what Daqo earns across a full polysilicon cycle, not just at the inflection point.

Polysilicon completed a full cycle from June 2020 ($6.75/kg) to August 2022 ($39/kg) and back to late 2023 ($6.75/kg again). The upcycle lasted roughly 18 months while the downturn lasted about 16 months. Based on this pattern, here's what normalized economics look like:

Mid-Cycle Assumptions:

  • Polysilicon price: $12-14/kg (midpoint between trough of $7/kg and sustainable high of $18-20/kg)
  • Capacity utilization: 65% (190,000 MT annually vs 305,000 MT nameplate)
  • Cash costs: $4.75/kg (modestly higher than Q3's $4.54/kg due to input inflation)
  • Total production costs: $6.25/kg (includes depreciation)

Mid-Cycle Economics:

  • Revenue: 190,000 MT $13/kg = $2.47 billion
  • Gross profit: 190,000 MT ($13 - $6.25) = $1.28 billion (52% gross margin)
  • Less SG&A: $128 million
  • EBITDA: ~$1.15 billion (47% EBITDA margin)
  • Less depreciation: ~$300 million
  • Operating income: ~$850 million
  • After-tax: ~$640 million (25% tax rate)

At $2.64 billion market cap with $2.21 billion in cash, the operating business trades at $440 million enterprise value. Mid-cycle normalized earnings of $640 million imply a 1.5x P/E on the operating assetsattractive if you believe mid-cycle conditions persist for 2-3 years out of every 5-year cycle.

The problem is cyclical asymmetry. During 18-month upcycles at $18-20/kg pricing, Daqo might generate $1.2-1.5 billion in cumulative earnings. But during 24-month downturns at $5-7/kg pricing, the company burns through $200-400 million in cumulative losses. The fortress balance sheet matters because it funds the losses during troughs, but the operating business itself doesn't compound valueit redistributes it from weak cycles to strong ones.

For the current $32.95 ADS price to work, you need to believe either: (1) this cycle's peak lasts longer than historical 18-month upcycles, or (2) industry consolidation permanently reduces capacity enough that mid-cycle prices settle at $14-16/kg instead of $12-14/kg. Neither seems obviously true based on China's track record of production discipline.

Visualizing the Profitability Window

The polysilicon price cycle over the past five years tells the story clearly. Prices started at $6.75/kg in June 2020, surged to $39/kg by August 2022, then collapsed back to $4.19/kg by Q1 2024 before recovering to current levels around $8.30/kg. Plotting Daqo's cash costs ($4.50-5.00/kg range) and total production costs ($6.25-7.25/kg range) against this price history shows how narrow the profitability window actually is. The company operated below cash costs for four consecutive quarters in 2024, meaning every kilogram produced burned cash. Even at today's $8.30/kg price, Daqo barely covers total costs including depreciation. The chart makes obvious what the financials confirmthis business only generates attractive returns during brief 12-18 month windows when prices spike above $15/kg, which happened for maybe 15 months out of the past 60. The other 45 months were either marginal or cash-burning.

Comparative Analysis: Daqo vs. Tongwei vs. GCL Technology

Daqo's position becomes clearer when benchmarked against the industry's top two producers.

Tongwei (910,000 MT capacity, 3.0x Daqo's size):

  • Vertically integrated across polysilicon, wafers, cells, and modules
  • Operated at 100% capacity utilization even during downturn due to internal consumption
  • H1 2025: RMB 4.96 billion net loss on RMB 40.5 billion revenue
  • Q3 2025: Reduced losses to RMB 315 million from RMB 2.36 billion in Q2
  • Cash costs estimated at RMB 35/kg (~$4.90/kg), slightly above Daqo's $4.54/kg

Tongwei's vertical integration provides natural hedgingwhen polysilicon prices collapse, downstream wafer and cell margins expand. However, it also constrains strategic flexibility. Tongwei cannot easily curtail polysilicon production without disrupting its own wafer supply chain, forcing it to operate at higher utilization rates even at losses. This makes Tongwei the price-setting marginal producer; its cash cost of ~$4.90/kg effectively establishes the floor price below which the industry sheds capacity.

GCL Technology (480,000 MT capacity, 1.6x Daqo's size):

  • Second-largest pure-play polysilicon producer
  • Q3 2025: PV materials business returned to profitability with RMB 960 million profit vs. RMB 1.81 billion loss in Q3 2024
  • Less transparent cost reporting, but industry sources suggest cash costs of RMB 40-45/kg (~$5.60-6.30/kg)
  • Operating rates between 30-60% during downturn

GCL's faster return to profitability compared to Daqo in Q3 suggests either superior cost structure or more aggressive inventory drawdowns. However, GCL's larger capacity and higher estimated cash costs mean it faces steeper challenges sustaining profitability if prices retreat from current levels.

Daqo's Competitive Position: At $4.54/kg cash costs, Daqo ranks among the global cost leaders, trailing only Tongwei's estimated $4.90/kg and well below the industry average of $5.50-6.50/kg. This cost advantage is criticalin commodity businesses, low-cost producers survive downturns while high-cost capacity exits. China's 6.4 kg/kg-Si energy consumption standard reinforces Daqo's position by forcing inefficient producers to either improve or shut down.

However, Daqo's pure-play exposure means it absorbs full commodity price volatility. While Tongwei loses money on polysilicon during downturns, it partially offsets losses through downstream margins. Daqo enjoys no such buffer. The company's smaller scale also limits negotiating power with suppliers of silicon metal and electricity.

Supply Chain and Input Cost Dynamics

Polysilicon production requires three critical inputs: silicon metal, electricity, and coal. The math on input costs isn't encouraging.

Silicon metal represents the primary raw material at roughly $1.40-1.60/kg currently. It takes 3.5-4.0 kg of silicon metal to produce 1 kg of polysilicon, implying $4.90-6.40/kg in raw material costs. Forecasts project Northeast Asian silicon metal prices rising 7% annually, adding $0.35-0.40/kg to Daqo's cost structure by 2027.

Electricity costs run $5.88-6.22 per MWh in Xinjiang, contributing roughly $0.60/kg to polysilicon production at 52-55 kWh per kg consumption rates. Daqo benefits from abundant coal-fired and renewable generation in Xinjiang, but seasonal variations affect pricing. A 2% annual electricity cost increase adds another $0.01-0.02/kg.

The compounding effect matters. With 7% annual silicon metal inflation plus 2% electricity inflation, Daqo faces ~$0.40/kg in cumulative cost headwinds by 2027. If selling prices stay flat at $8/kg while costs rise from $6.38/kg to $6.78/kg in 2026 and $7.18/kg in 2027, the already-thin margins evaporate. This is why the through-cycle analysis mattersinput cost inflation runs 5-7% annually while polysilicon prices historically mean-revert, creating a margin squeeze during the back half of every cycle.

Valuation and Investment Framework

At $32.95 per ADS ($2.2 billion market capitalization), Daqo trades at 0.63x book value of $3.5 billion. This discount reflects the market's assessment that the company's assets cannot generate returns commensurate with their carrying valuea judgment supported by the operating reality. At 40% utilization and $5.80/kg pricing, return on assets approximates 1.3% ($84M owner cash flow $6.7B gross PP&E), well below any reasonable cost of capital.

The company's $2.21 billion in cash and investments represents 98% of the market capitalization, implying investors value the operating business at just $440 million. Stated differently, the market prices Daqo's production capacity at $1.44/kg of annual nameplate capacity ($440M 305,000 MT)a business generating $1.26/kg in gross cash at 40% utilization.

For Daqo to generate acceptable owner returns, the investment thesis requires belief in three sequential developments:

First, polysilicon prices must sustainably exceed $8.00/kg to cover total costs including depreciation and overhead. Current prices of $8.30/kg represent meaningful improvement from Q3's $5.80/kg, but whether this level persists depends entirely on industry production discipline.

Second, capacity utilization must approach 65-75% to spread fixed costs appropriately. At 40% utilization, each kilogram of production absorbs 2.5x its proportionate share of depreciation and overhead. Higher utilization dilutes this burden, but requires either Daqo taking market share from competitors or industry-wide demand growth outpacing supply additions.

Third, input costs must remain stable or decline. With silicon metal prices forecast to rise 7% annually and electricity costs growing 2% annually, the cost structure faces $0.40-0.50/kg in cumulative headwinds by 2027. Unless production efficiencies offset these increases, margins compress even if selling prices hold steady.

Historical polysilicon cycles suggest prices above $9.00/kg attract new capacity within 18-24 months, limiting the duration of high-margin periods. Conversely, prices below $6.00/kg force capacity rationalization but inflict cumulative losses during extended troughs. The question for potential owners is whether Daqo's cost leadership and balance sheet strength position it to capture disproportionate value during the next upcycle relative to the losses absorbed during downturns.

Risk/Reward Assessment

The skew of outcomes favors caution. Bull case requires near-perfect execution of industry consolidation, sustained demand growth, and stable input coststhree conditions that must align simultaneously. Base case requires only moderate improvement from current state but offers limited upside given current valuation. Bear case requires merely a return to early-2025 conditions if consolidation efforts fail.

Polysilicon prices as of early January 2026 have continued recovering, reaching RMB 59,200/MT ($8.30/kg) with new orders above RMB 60,000/MT ($8.40/kg). This represents a 45% increase from Q3 2025's $5.80/kg and suggests the industry's coordinated capacity cuts are having near-term effects. However, sustainability remains questionable. The China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association projects January 2026 production could fall to 60,000-80,000 MT (from 115,000 MT in December 2025), but industry analyst Johannes Bernreuter cautions that Chinese polysilicon and wafer producers have historically failed to maintain production discipline once prices recover.

Conclusion

Daqo New Energy has executed well within its controlachieving industry-leading cash costs, maintaining a fortress balance sheet, and surviving a brutal two-year downturn that forced weaker competitors into bankruptcy. The Q3 2025 inflection point demonstrates the company's operational excellence and cost discipline. However, Daqo cannot control polysilicon prices, which remain the dominant variable determining shareholder returns.

The fundamental challenge is that Daqo operates a capital-intensive, commodity manufacturing business in a structurally oversupplied industry where China's top four producers control 65% of global capacity and built two-thirds of new capacity between 2020-2024. For shares to deliver attractive long-term returns from current levels, polysilicon prices must sustain $8.00-9.00/kg for multiple yearsa scenario that historically attracts new capacity and triggers the next downcycle.

The current price recovery to $8.30/kg provides a tactical window for Daqo to rebuild margins and cash generation. Whether this represents a genuine inflection or merely a cyclical bounce will be determined by whether Chinese producers can enforce production discipline once prices reach profitable levels. History suggests they cannot. For investors willing to underwrite commodity cycles and bet on Daqo's survival as a low-cost producer, current valuations may offer value. For those seeking stable, predictable returns, the risk/reward profile warrants caution until multiple quarters of sustained profitability demonstrate the inflection is real rather than transitory.

data.title: The new anti-AI trade sweeping Wall Street: 'HALO'
data.description:
Suddenly, what's old is new again.

There's a popular trade sweeping Wall Street that's offering an old world solution to the threat of AI disruption: "HALO," or "Heavy Assets, Low Obsolescence."

What that means is that more investors are betting that companies with hefty real assets such as grids, pipelines and heavy machinery are the ones least likely to be replaced by artificial intelligence.

"I've come up with a term for the types of stocks that have run away with the stock market's gains this year. They are the HALO part of the market," investor Josh Brown wrote for CNBC earlier this month.

"They have risks, but not AI risks. In fact, in many cases, AI will probably enable them to become even more profitable than they are today," Brown continued. "So they actually go up as the LLMs advance."

That idea is central to why many real world sectors are outperforming this year, even as the overall market and especially tech stocks have floundered. The two top-performing sectors are energy and materials, which are surging more than 23% and 15%, respectively. The third best-performing sector, consumer staples, has rallied more than 14%.

Compare that to the market cap weighted S&P 500, which is just slightly higher year to date.

Or even more worryingly, tech stocks. Only two of the "Magnificent Seven" names are higher this year, failing to rally even off the back of Nvidia's earnings beat, as investors worry their massive capex spending may not be justified.

Software stocks are lost in a bloodbath amid fears that advances coming out of Anthropic around agentic AI will cripple an industry reliant on scalability and high fees. The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF (IGV) is down more than 22% this year, and more than 30% off its recent high.

And financials and commercial real estate are two other areas that have been hurt.

The term has been quickly adopted on other parts of the Street. A note from the Barclays' trading desk last week said "HALO" names have benefited from the "violent" move into the more defensive parts of the market.

Goldman Sachs' Guillaume Jaisson said that markets have been rewarding HALO, saying a basket of its capital intensive names have outperformed capital light stocks by 35% since 2025.

A note from the sales desk at Bank of America said HALO is a way for investors to avoid near-term volatility by taking advantage of a secular rotation into old economy cyclicals.

To be sure, there are many who worry that the panic selling that has defined the market as of late has been indiscriminate. As an example, some expect software stocks could be nearing a bottom, with some even emerging as winners despite the cascade of advances out of Anthropic.

In fact, tech is now about as cheap as consumer staples, suggesting the growth names are not nearly as overvalued as investors feared.

"The test for investors going forward will be whether [HALO] remains the correct investment as the AI narrative once again evolves, especially as the capex hump of hyperscalers is passed," read a note last week from the Barclays' trading desk.

Yet the HALO crowd have reason to believe the trade is sustainable. Outside of a desire to escape the market's next AI victim, many HALO stocks have room to run after years of underperformance, can benefit from easier monetary policy and fiscal stimulus, and could even realize improved margins from AI.

Here are some of the HALO beneficiaries that Bank of America's sales desk identified.

Apple is just one of two Mag Seven companies that has eked out a gain this year, with the other advancer being Nvidia. The iPhone maker underperformed its cohort last year, yet investors are hopeful that the tech giant's foray into AI tied to its devices will revive the stock.

Chevron is another example. The oil and gas giant, which is up more than 20% this year, was recently upgraded to buy at Melius Research because of an expected pickup in exploration.

data.title: CORRECTION FROM SOURCE: Video - CEO Clips Bold Ventures Advances Exploration at Burchell and Highlights Ring of Fire
data.description:
This release corrects and replaces the press release issued by CEO Clips on [Feb 27, 2026] at [12:00 PM EST]. In the headline correcting Virtual to Burchell. 

Vancouver, British Columbia--(Newsfile Corp. - February 28, 2026) - Bold Ventures Inc. is advancing exploration at its Burchell property in Ontario, following a new gold discovery with samples up to 68 grams per tonne. The company is awaiting results from recent winter drilling while also monitoring activities in the Ring of Fire region.

Bold Ventures Inc.

https://www.boldventuresinc.com/

For over 25 years, BTV has been a capital markets focused TV production and Digital Marketing Agency. BTV helps companies increase their brand awareness to a national retail and institutional investor audience, combining unique content creation and major distribution services on top tier networks including Bloomberg, CNBC, FOX Business News and financial sites. The BTV suite of strategic products include: BTV- Business Television Show, CEO Clips™, TV Branding Ads, Digital, Lead Gen, Social and Direct Email Marketing Campaigns that reach investors where they research and live on-air and online.

data.title: Bitcoin bottom fractal calls for 130% rally, but is the model valid in 2026?
data.description:
A Bitcoin (BTC) bottom signal that appeared in 2023, ahead of a 130% rally in 2024, has flashed again this week, raising the possibility that the price is nearing another bullish inflection point. 

At the same time, the broader data of liquidity, exchange-traded fund (ETF) flows, and macroeconomic data changes the environment from two years ago, suggesting that the path forward may not mirror the previous cycle’s.

BTC bottom trigger appears without strong follow-through

Data aggregator Swissblock noted that Bitcoin has now logged 25 consecutive days in its “extreme high risk” zone, the longest stretch on record and above the 23-day peak seen in 2023. Historically, an extended stay in this zone has aligned with late-stage drawdowns or a bottom signal.

MN Capital founder Michaël van de Poppe also pointed to the BTC versus supply in the profit/loss chart, which shows the price interacting with levels that previously marked bottoming phases. In 2023, the shift from high risk to low risk coincided with the start of a powerful bullish expansion.

Trader positioning is not in sync with an uptrend. RugaResearch noted that 30-day apparent demand continues to flip between positive and negative. While the selling pressure has faded, sustained buying demand has not maintained its dominance.

Related: Bitcoin to $30K? Analysts debate when and at what price BTC will bottom

Deeper Bitcoin drawdowns take time

Macroeconomic newsletter Ecoinometrics highlighted that a BTC decline of this magnitude rarely resolves quickly. Excluding the 2020 COVID rally, which was supported by aggressive monetary policy intervention, the recoveries from 50% drawdowns developed over an extended period.

The ETF flow data reinforces the cautious tone. Since August, cumulative inflows into gold ETFs have surpassed spot Bitcoin ETF flows on a 90-day rolling basis. Over the same period, Bitcoin funds have posted negative flows on a 90-day average rolling basis, currently sitting at –$2.06 billion. 

The inflation trends added further context. Ecoinometrics noted that the headline Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) sits near 2.9% year-on-year, with core near 3.0% and core services above 3.4%. The Federal Reserve targets PCE, and the recent trend has not shown a clear downward shift. Without easing expectations, the liquidity expansion looks limited.

The price levels frame the debate. CMCC Crest Managing Partner Willy Woo said that any short-term relief rally to $70,000 to $80,000 is likely to be met with another round of selling pressure, since “the broader regime is heavily bearish with both spot and futures liquidity deteriorating”.

Woo said that the $45,000 level aligns with the prior bear market. Below that, $30,000 and $16,000 mark the historical support, which is tied to longer-term trend preservation. 

Related: Crypto taxes updated, BTC stuck below $70K: Month in charts

data.description: This news item displays a headline only and has no other text.

data.title: Key facts: Microsoft a top investment; AI clients could boost revenue by $40B
data.description:
• Dan Ives from Wedbush Securities sees Microsoft as a top investment, noting 10% of Azure clients are pursuing AI, which could boost revenue by $35-$40 billion.1
  • Amdocs and Microsoft are collaborating to provide AI-driven application modernization solutions, utilizing Microsoft's AI tools like Azure Open AI and GitHub Copilot to improve cloud migration.2

data.title: Key facts: Hawaiian Electric posts $40M Q4 profit; wildfire safety plan approved
data.description:
• Hawaiian Electric Industries posted a Q4 profit of $40 million for 2025, rebounding from a $68 million loss in 2024, with revenues of $805.8 million driven by renewable energy efforts.12
  • In December 2025, regulators approved Hawaiian Electric's wildfire safety plan, enhancing technology, strengthening infrastructure, and boosting community partnerships to reduce wildfire risks.3

data.title: Key facts: Frontline Plc secures high VLCC rates; new director appointed
data.description:
• Frontline Plc secured 92% of Q1 2026 VLCC spot days at $107,100 per day, the highest since Q2 2008. An analyst raised the price target for FRO from $31 to $42.1
  • Frontline Plc announced the resignation of Director Ørjan Svanevik, appointing Mikkel Storm Weum as his replacement. Weum has experience in investment and advanced degrees in naval architecture.23

data.title: Key facts: FMC Corporation declares dividend; appoints Michael F. Barry
data.description:
• FMC Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of 8 cents per share, scheduled for payment on April 16, 2026, to shareholders on record as of March 31, 2026.1
  • FMC Corporation appointed Michael F. Barry to its Board of Directors on February 27, 2026. Barry brings over 30 years of specialty chemicals experience and will join key committees.2

data.title: Key facts: Blackstone reports $14.45B revenue; CEO earns $1.2B; plans AI firm
data.description:
• Blackstone Inc. reported $14.45 billion in revenue for the year, a 9% rise from last year, driven by increased Management and Advisory Fees and Investment Income.1
  • In 2025, Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman earned over $1.2 billion, with $1.1 billion from dividends on his 20% stake, despite a 7.9% drop in share performance.2
  • Blackstone has announced plans to establish a public company dedicated to acquiring AI data centers, aiming to leverage the increasing demand for AI infrastructure.3

data.title: Key facts: BlackRock, Goldman Sachs partner on pension funding; fund distributions shift to quarterly
data.description:
• BlackRock has formed a partnership with Goldman Sachs to enter the pension funding sector, specifically targeting Phoenix's pension business.1
  • On February 27, 2026, BlackRock announced it will shift certain closed-end funds from monthly to quarterly distributions, while maintaining monthly payments for April, May, and June 2026.2

data.title: Key facts: Berkshire Hathaway Q4 profit drops 30%; annual report pending
data.description:
• Berkshire Hathaway's Q4 operating profit dropped 30% to $10.2 billion due to investment writedowns. Full-year operating profit fell 6% to $44.49 billion, with net income down 25% to $67 billion.123
  • Berkshire Hathaway will soon release its annual report and Q4 earnings, showcasing new CEO Greg Abel's focus on a strong balance sheet and $373.3 billion cash reserve, with no dividend plans.45

data.title: Key facts: Alphabet shares rise 1.4% after Trump order; Amdocs partners with Google Cloud
data.description:
• Alphabet shares rose 1.4% to $311.43 after President Trump ordered federal agencies to stop using Anthropic's AI models, potentially benefiting Google's AI model, Gemini.1
  • Amdocs partners with Google Cloud to boost AI in telecommunications, developing a generative contact center that combines Google Cloud's Gemini with Amdocs' Cognitive Core for enhanced efficiency.2

data.title: Key facts: Sunrun Inc. stock drops 35%; Q4 2025 sees 17% subscriber decline
data.description:
• Sunrun Inc. (RUN) experienced a 35% decline in its stock price following a disappointing cash flow outlook for 2026, which prompted a downgrade by Jefferies analysts.1
  • In Q4 2025, Sunrun Inc. saw a 17% drop in new subscribers and a 30% decline in the net value per customer, indicating a slowdown in residential solar demand.2

data.title: Key facts: Rocket Lab secures $816M satellite contract; achieves 100% success in hypersonic tests
data.description:
• Rocket Lab has won an $816 million contract from the Space Development Agency to build 18 satellites, the largest in its history, with 37% of its backlog expected to generate revenue soon.1
  • On February 27, 2026, Rocket Lab launched its second hypersonic test mission for the Department of War, achieving a 100% success rate across seven HASTE launches.2

data.title: Key facts: Paramount Skydance to Acquire Warner Bros. for $81B; Deal Faces Regulatory Scrutiny
data.description:
• Warner Bros. Discovery will be acquired by Paramount Skydance for $31.00 per share, valuing it at $81 billion. The deal is set to close in Q3 2026, pending approvals.123
  • Warner Bros. Discovery faces challenges from falling linear subscribers and ad revenue, along with risks tied to the PSKY Merger needing regulatory and shareholder approvals.4
  • California regulators are reviewing Warner Bros. Discovery's acquisition, with the Attorney General investigating potential impacts on consumer choice and job losses in the cinema sector.5

data.title: Key facts: Goldman Sachs shares fall 7.4%; asset management redemptions drop
data.description:
• Goldman Sachs (GS) shares dropped 7.4% on Friday, the largest decline since April, due to concerns over AI impacts, inflation, and challenges in private credit amid a broader bank selloff.1
  • Goldman Sachs' asset management division reported a fourth-quarter redemption rate of 3.5% at GS Credit, notably lower than the over 5% redemption rate observed among its competitors.2

data.title: Oil Set to Rise Sharply
data.description:
Oil prices are set to jump sharply when trading resumes Sunday night, as unprecedented U.S. and Israeli strikes on Iran have intensified Middle East tensions and heightened concerns over potential disruptions to global energy supplies.

Prices have been supported since the start of the year by persistent geopolitical tensions.

On Friday, WTI crude futures climbed to around $67 per barrel, hovering near a seven-month high, as traders reacted nervously to reports that U.S. officials left talks in Geneva disappointed with the lack of progress, even as Iranian and Omani participants struck a more optimistic tone.

data.title: Brent Set to Jump
data.description:
Oil prices are set to jump sharply when trading resumes Sunday night, as unprecedented U.S. and Israeli strikes on Iran have intensified Middle East tensions and heightened concerns over potential disruptions to global energy supplies.

Prices have been supported since the start of the year by persistent geopolitical tensions.

On Friday, brent futures climbed to around $73 per barrel, hitting near 8-month high, as traders reacted nervously to reports that U.S. officials left talks in Geneva disappointed with the lack of progress, even as Iranian and Omani participants struck a more optimistic tone.

data.title: Market analysts react to US-Israel strikes on Iran
data.description:
The United States and Israel launched strikes on Iran on Saturday, targeting its leadership and plunging the Middle East into a new conflict that President Donald Trump said would end a security threat and give Iranians a chance to topple their rulers.

The strikes put nearby oil-producing Gulf Arab countries on edge as fears of escalation grew, and Tehran responded by launching missiles towards Israel.

Some oil majors and top trading houses suspended crude oil and fuel shipments via the Strait of Hormuz because of the attacks, four trading sources said on Saturday.

QUOTES:

ENERGY ANALYSTS AT EURASIA GROUP:

"Oil prices will rise sharply when markets open. Should the conflict continue into Sunday, oil prices are likely to respond by increasing by $5-10 above the current $73 baseline, based on Iran's claim to have closed the Strait of Hormuz and the disruption in tanker traffic."

ENERGY ANALYSTS AT BARCLAYS:

"Oil markets might have to face their worst fears on Monday. As things stand right now, we think Brent could hit $100 (per barrel), as the market grapples with the threat of a potential supply disruption amid a spiralling security situation in the Middle East."

VISHNU VARATHAN, HEAD OF MACRO RESEARCH, ASIA EX-JAPAN, MIZUHO, SINGAPORE:

"A broader state of spots of regional attacks/instability may be par for the course - in line with Iran’s warning. Oil prices are likely to remain elevated as production and passage remain prone to attacks and disruptions. OPEC may be under pressure to raise production to try and offset. But a 10-25% premium on oil is not outlandish - even without a blockade of the Strait of Hormuz, which is easily a 50% premium risk event."

CHRISTOPHER WONG, STRATEGIST, OCBC, SINGAPORE:

"The strike raises geopolitical risk premia as markets head into Monday’s open. The immediate reaction function is fairly predictable: safe-haven assets such as gold are likely to see an upside gap, while oil prices may also firm on supply-disruption concerns. Risk assets and high-beta currencies … could face an initial bout of volatility, particularly if headlines suggest potential retaliation or regional spillovers."

NICK FERRES, CIO, VANTAGE POINT ASSET MANAGEMENT, SINGAPORE:

"Energy is still inexpensive. That’s the obvious sector that rallies on Monday. And gold."

data.title: Iran conflict raises talk of a return to $100-a-barrel oil
data.description:
By Myra P. Saefong

Reports say Iran's military is not allowing passage through the crucial maritime waterway known as the Strait of Hormuz

Sealing the Straight of Hormuz would be the economic equivalent of pulling the fire alarm in a crowded theatre, says SPI Asset Management.

The U.S. and Israel's attack on Iran raised alarms on Saturday that a key regional source of the world's crude oil may now be at risk, sparking talk of a return to $100-a-barrel oil prices.

The Strait of Hormuz, a maritime chokepoint vital to the world's crude-oil exports, has come into sharp focus as fears of a broader regional conflict grow. The strait is crucial because it allows cargo ships to pass the Persian Gulf, the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea, facilitating the production and flow of crude oil from the Middle East. The region is home to five of the world's top 10 biggest producers.

"So far, there is no clarity on the magnitude of any energy disruptions, but there has been some disruption of shipping in the Strait of Hormuz," said Matt Gertken, chief geopolitical and U.S. political strategist at BCA Research. "It is too soon to gauge the impact on the oil market, but the intensity of the military operation implies high odds of a major oil supply disruption" of 5 million barrels per day or more, he told MarketWatch on Saturday.

The U.S. and Israel strikes on Iran targeted its leadership and military assets, The Wall Street Journal reported. The move followed failed negotiations between the U.S. and Iran to reach a deal to limit Iran's nuclear program. Iran has responded with strikes across the Middle East.

Read: Trump calls for regime change after U.S.-Israel attack on Iran. Markets should brace for more than June's brief military campaign.

Several news reports Saturday indicated that passage through the Strait of Hormuz has been curtailed. An official from the European Union's naval mission Aspides told Reuters that vessels have been receiving VHF transmission from Iran's Revolutionary Guards saying that no ship is allowed to pass the Strait of Hormuz. So far, there has not been any official closure announcement.

'Iran understands that sealing Hormuz is the economic equivalent of pulling the fire alarm in a crowded theatre and locking the exits for Middle East oil exports.'Stephen Innes, SPI Asset Management

Iran, however, "understands that sealing Hormuz is the economic equivalent of pulling the fire alarm in a crowded theatre and locking the exits for Middle East oil exports," said Stephen Innes, managing partner at SPI Asset Management. "It would hit not only Western consumers but also China and regional buyers. It is a blunt instrument."

Developments in the region are sure to impact oil prices as soon as trading resumes late Sunday and into early Monday.

Oil prices will continue to rise on speculation that the war will expand and that infrastructure will be hit, said BCA Research's Gertken. U.S. global benchmark Brent crude (BRN00) could reach $90 per barrel without significant physical disruption, he said. That would be a more than 20% rise from Friday's settlement of $72.87 for the May contract (BRNK26).

If there is physical disruption, then it can rise above $100 per barrel - "potentially well above" that, said Gertken.

Strait of Hormuz: A staggering chokepoint

Just how much oil could be involved when it comes to the Strait of Hormuz and to the broader region is staggering. Kpler provided a snapshot Saturday of oil and oil-product tankers in the Strait of Hormuz.

This map is a snapshot of the oil and oil-product tankers currently in and around the Strait Hormuz. Green tankers are loaded, while red ones are in "ballast," or essentially empty.

Around 20% of the global petroleum liquids the world uses transits through the strait each day. Last year, just over 14.5 million barrels per day of crude and crude condensate exports passed through the strait, said Matt Smith, U.S. head analyst at Kpler.

From the archives: Strait of Hormuz, the world's biggest oil chokepoint, in focus as U.S.-Iran tensions flare

Saudi Arabia accounted for around 5.5 million daily barrels, Iraq 3.25 million, UAE 1.97 million, Iran 1.59 million, Kuwait 1.55 million, and Qatar 0.72 million, said Smith. Over 90% of that oil typically heads to Asia, around 4% to Europe, 4% to the Americas and the rest to Africa, he said.

Four countries - China, India, Japan and South Korea - account for nearly three-quarters of the crude barrels that pass through the Strait of Hormuz, so they would feel the most significant impact, said Smith.

The Middle East is home to half of the world's top 10 oil producers - Saudi Arabia, Iraq, the United Arab Emirates, Iran and Kuwait, according to the International Energy Agency. In 2022, the region accounted for more than four in 10 barrels of global oil exports, it said.

Yet the oil market's biggest risk isn't the Strait of Hormuz being closed, said Kpler's Smith. It's that "Iran's retaliation leads to broader unrest in the region, putting supply at risk," he said.

Iran alone produces 3.2 million daily barrels of crude oil, with around 2 million of that primarily exported to China for refining, according to OPIS, a unit of Dow Jones, the publisher of MarketWatch.

Iran's proven crude oil reserves are estimated at 208 billion barrels, according to OPIS.

There have been reports of explosions Iran's Kharg Island, a key export terminal roughly 15 miles off the coast of Iran, OPIS's Denton Cinquegrana and Tracy Cui wrote in a report Saturday. It is still too early to tell what kind of damage, if any, has been done to export infrastructure on Kharg Island, they said, but about 90% of Iran's exports go through it. Sometimes called "oil island," it has a storage capacity of about 7 million barrels.

From the archives: Israeli strikes on Iran's 'oil island' could send crude prices soaring

OPEC+ meeting Sunday

The Iran conflict comes ahead of Sunday's monthly meeting of eight major oil producers, a group known as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies, or OPEC+.

The group had been raising their production quotas for most of last year, but paused those increases for the first quarter of 2026 on the heels of expectations for a global oil supply surplus.

Now OPEC+ is likely to increase production to "try to suppress prices, cushion the global economy, and undercut Iranian regime funding," said BCA Research's Gertken. But if shipping is affected, then any such production increases "may not be able to reach the global market immediately."

Read: Any chance of a Fed interest-rate cut in 2026 is 'evaporating before our very eyes' with Iran war set to stoke oil prices

-Myra P. Saefong

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: DBV Technologies Highlights Additional Data from Successful Phase 3 VITESSE Study at the AAAAI 2026 Annual Meeting
data.description:
Châtillon, France, February 28, 2026

DBV Technologies Highlights Additional Data from Successful Phase 3 VITESSE Study at the AAAAI 2026 Annual Meeting

  • Approximately 83% of children treated with the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch increased their eliciting dose at month 12, compared to approximately 48% in the placebo group
  • Approximately 60% of children treated with the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch increased their eliciting dose by at least two doses at month 12, compared to 23% in the placebo group
  • 24% of children on placebo decreased their eliciting dose between the baseline and month 12 double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge, compared to only 6.4% of children treated with the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch

DBV Technologies Euronext:DBV – ISIN:FR0010417345 – Nasdaq Stock Market:DBVT, a late-stage biopharmaceutical company, today announced that the company shared additional positive data from the successful Phase 3 VITESSE clinical trial as an oral presentation today at the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (AAAAI) 2026 Annual Meeting, in Philadelphia, PA. VITESSE, the largest food allergy immunotherapy trial to date, is a Phase 3 study assessing DBV’s VIASKIN® Peanut Patch for the treatment of peanut-allergic children aged 4 to 7 years.

The VITESSE study met its primary endpoint whereby VIASKIN Peanut demonstrated a statistically significant treatment effect (p<0.001), with 46.6% of children in the VIASKIN Peanut arm meeting the treatment responder criteria* at 12 months, as compared to 14.8% of children in the placebo arm (difference in response rates = 31.8%; 95% confidence interval (CI) = (24.5, 39.0%)), exceeding the lower bound prespecified threshold of 15%.

Highlights from the data presented at AAAAI 2026:

  • 82.8% of subjects treated with the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch increased their eliciting dose by at least one dose, or one incremental step in a double-blind placebo-controlled food challenge, at month 12, compared to approximately 48% in the placebo group.
  • 60.1% of the treated subjects increased their eliciting dose by at least two doses of the double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge at month 12, compared to 23.4% in the placebo group.
  • 24% of subjects on placebo decreased their eliciting dose between the baseline and month 12 double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge, compared to only 6.4% of treated subjects.
  • All sensitivity analyses were statistically significant with the 95% CI exceeding the lower bound prespecified threshold of 15%, ranging from 22.1% to 27.8%, confirming the robustness of the primary endpoint analysis.
  • In both baseline eliciting dose (ED) strata, a significantly greater proportion of children treated with the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch were treatment responders as compared to the placebo group.
    • Among children with a baseline ED ≤ 30mg, 49.3% were responders versus 14.7% in the placebo group (△=34.6%; 95% CI:24.93, 44.24).
    • Among children with a baseline ED = 100mg, 43.1% were responders versus 14.6% in the placebo group (△=28.5%; 95% CI:17.51, 39.5).
  • The VIASKIN® Peanut Patch was well tolerated; the majority of treatment emergent adverse events (TEAEs) were mild local application site reactions, consistent with DBV’s previous Phase 3 studies.

“Building on the statistically significant topline results from the VITESSE Phase 3 study, the additional data presented at this year’s AAAAI Annual Meeting suggest a broad and consistent treatment effect of the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch, regardless of baseline eliciting dose strata or study population analysis,” stated David Fleischer M.D., Professor of Pediatrics at Children’s Hospital Colorado and Global Principal Investigator of the VITESSE study. “The increases in eliciting dose seen are clinically meaningful and may reflect a reduced risk of an allergic reaction. Conversely, nearly four times as many children on placebo saw their eliciting dose decrease, becoming more sensitized over the twelve-month period. These results not only support the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch as a potential treatment option for peanut-allergic children, if approved, but also reinforce the importance of prioritizing a proactive treatment for this specific patient population."

“We believe the additional data presented today demonstrate that the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch consistently induced desensitization among subjects irrespective of study subgroup or baseline characteristics,” stated Pharis Mohideen M.D., Chief Medical Officer of DBV Technologies. “If approved, the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch would provide caregivers with a non-invasive option that fits into daily activities. To that end, these data support a Biologics License Application, which we are planning to submit to FDA in the first half of this year.”

The presentation will be made available on the Scientific Publication & Presentations page on the Company’s website at https://dbv-technologies.com/events/aaaai-annual-meeting-2026/.

*Responders were defined as children with a baseline eliciting dose (ED) ≤30 mg who achieved an ED ≥300 mg of peanut protein at month 12, or children with a baseline ED = 100 mg who achieved an ED ≥600 mg of peanut protein at month 12, as measured by a double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge (DBPCFC). The ED is the amount of peanut protein that induced an allergic reaction.

About DBV Technologies

DBV Technologies is a late-stage biopharmaceutical company developing treatment options for food allergies and other immunologic conditions with significant unmet medical need. DBV Technologies is currently focused on investigating the use of its proprietary VIASKIN® patch technology to address food allergies, which are caused by a hypersensitive immune reaction and characterized by a range of symptoms varying in severity from mild to life-threatening anaphylaxis. Millions of people live with food allergies, including young children. Through epicutaneous immunotherapy (EPIT), the VIASKIN® Patch is designed to introduce microgram amounts of a biologically active compound to the immune system through intact skin. EPIT is a new class of non-invasive treatment that seeks to modify an individual’s underlying allergy by re-educating the immune system to become desensitized to allergen by leveraging the skin’s immune tolerizing properties. DBV Technologies is committed to transforming the care of food allergic people. The Company’s food allergy programs include ongoing clinical trials of the VIASKIN® Peanut Patch in peanut allergic toddlers (1 through 3 years of age) and children (4 through 7 years of age).

DBV Technologies is headquartered in Châtillon, France, with North American operations in Warren, NJ. The Company’s ordinary shares are traded on segment B of Euronext Paris (DBV, ISIN code:FR0010417345 and the Company’s ADSs (each representing five ordinary shares) are traded on the Nasdaq Capital Market (DBVT – CUSIP:23306J309.

For more information, please visit www.dbv-technologies.com and engage with us on X (formerly Twitter) and LinkedIn.

Forward Looking Statements

This press release may contain forward-looking statements and estimates, including statements regarding the therapeutic potential of VIASKIN® Peanut patch and EPIT, results of DBV’s clinical trials, DBV’s planned regulatory and clinical efforts including timing and results of communications with regulatory agencies, plans and expectations with respect to the submission of BLAs to FDA, and the ability of any of DBV’s product candidates, if approved, to improve the lives of patients with food allergies. These forward-looking statements and estimates are not promises or guarantees and involve substantial risks and uncertainties. At this stage, DBV’s product candidates have not been authorized for sale in any country. Among the factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those described or projected herein include uncertainties associated generally with research and development, clinical trials and related regulatory reviews and approvals, and DBV’s ability to successfully execute on its budget discipline measures. A further list and description of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements in this press release can be found in DBV’s regulatory filings with the French Autorité des Marchés Financiers (“AMF”), DBV’s filings and reports with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (“SEC”), including in DBV’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2024, filed with the SEC on April 11, 2025, as amended by Amendment No. 1 on Form 10-K/A filed with the SEC on April 28, 2025, and as amended further by Amendment No. 2 on Form 10-K/A filed with the SEC on May 14, 2025, and future filings and reports made with the AMF and SEC by DBV. Existing and prospective investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements and estimates, which speak only as of the date hereof. Other than as required by applicable law, DBV Technologies undertakes no obligation to update or revise the information contained in this Press Release.

The Company reminds that the going concern assessment is made as of the date of this press release based on management’s current assumptions. In accordance with U.S. GAAP, IFRS, SEC and AMF rules, the Company will update its going‑concern evaluation as of the issuance of its Annual Report on Form 10‑K and the universal registration document.

VIASKIN is a registered trademark of DBV Technologies.

Investor Relations Contact

Jonathan Neely

DBV Technologies

jonathan.neely@dbv-technologies.com

Media Contact

brett.whelan@dbv-technologies.com
